docs.title: Initializer for Apache Maven™ — Technical Documentation
docs.text:
Welcome to the technical documentation for Initializer for Apache Maven™.

This site contains:

  • Architecture overview — High-level structure of the application and its main components.
  • Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) — List of ADRs with links to each decision record.

Initializer for Apache Maven™ is a web application that helps you bootstrap production-ready Maven-based Java projects with a well-structured pom.xml, sensible defaults, and up-to-date dependencies.

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text: This document describes the high-level architecture of Initializer for Apache Maven™: how the system is structured and the role of each main part. It does not go into implementation details; those are covered in the codebase and in blog posts (e.g. the toolbox integration).

docs.title: High-Level Structure
docs.text:
Initializer for Apache Maven™ follows a layered architecture with a clear separation between the Frontend and the Backend. The diagram below shows the Frontend at the top and all other components grouped inside the Backend.

flowchart TB
    FE[Frontend]

    subgraph Backend["Backend"]
        API[REST API]
        PG[ProjectGeneratorService]
        AV[ArtifactVersionService]
        CFG[MavenToolboxConfig]
        TB[Maveniverse Toolbox]
    end

    FE --> API
    API --> PG
    PG --> AV
    PG --> TB
    AV --> TB
    CFG --> TB

docs.title: Main Components
docs.text:
• Frontend (Next.js) Single-page application that guides the user through project configuration and triggers generation. It is the only part that runs in the browser.

  • Backend All of the following components run in the backend (Spring Boot application):

    • ProjectController / REST API Entry point of the backend. Receives the project request DTO and delegates to the project generation service.

    • ProjectGeneratorService Orchestrates the full generation pipeline: creates the directory structure, resolves versions, generates and edits the POM, adds Maven Wrapper and README, and builds the ZIP.

    • ArtifactVersionService Resolves the latest (or requested) versions for dependencies and plugins from Maven repositories.

    • MavenToolboxConfig Configures the Maveniverse Toolbox context (e.g. settings, local repository) used by the backend.

    • Maveniverse Toolbox Library used for programmatic POM creation and editing, and for version resolution. All Maven-specific logic is encapsulated here.

docs.title: End-to-End Generation Flow
docs.text:
The full lifecycle of a project request is:

flowchart TB
    A[User submits form]
    B[Backend receives request]
    C[Create directory structure]
    D[Resolve dependency versions]
    E[Generate & edit pom.xml]
    F[Add Maven Wrapper]
    G[Generate README]
    H[Package ZIP]
    I[Download]

    A --> B --> C --> D --> E --> F --> G --> H --> I

docs.title: Version Resolution
docs.text:
The backend resolves dependency and plugin versions at generation time by querying Maven repositories, so generated projects use current stable versions instead of hard-coded ones.

sequenceDiagram
    participant PG as ProjectGeneratorService
    participant AV as ArtifactVersionService
    participant TR as ToolboxResolver
    participant MR as Maven Repositories

    PG ->> AV: resolveLatestVersion()
    AV ->> TR: findNewestVersion()
    TR ->> MR: query metadata
    MR -->> TR: available versions
    TR -->> AV: newest stable version
    AV -->> PG: version string

docs.title: POM Editing: Transactional Session
docs.text:
POM changes are applied inside a single editing session. Either all changes are committed, or the session is rolled back so the POM stays valid.

stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> OpenSession
    OpenSession --> EditPOM
    EditPOM --> Commit: success
    EditPOM --> Rollback: failure
    Commit --> [*]
    Rollback --> [*]

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
1. User configures the project in the frontend and submits the form.
  2. The frontend sends a project request to the backend REST API.
  3. The backend creates the project directory structure and a minimal POM.
  4. Dependency and plugin versions are resolved (using Toolbox and Maven repositories).
  5. The POM is completed inside a transactional edit session; other artifacts (Maven Wrapper, README) are generated.
  6. The project is packaged as a ZIP and returned to the user.

For more detail on how the toolbox is used (DSL, plugin configuration, etc.), see the related blog post and the backend source code.

docs.title: Contributing to the docs
docs.text: This folder contains the source for the Initializer for Apache Maven™ technical documentation (GitHub Pages).

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
• index.md — Landing page and entry point.
  • architecture.md — High-level architecture overview (no implementation details).
  • adr/ — Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) in Markdown.

The site is built with MkDocs and the Material for MkDocs theme. Configuration is in the repository root: mkdocs.yml.

docs.title: Building locally
docs.text:
From the repository root:

pip install mkdocs-material "pymdown-extensions"
mkdocs serve

Then open http://127.0.0.1:8000 .

docs.title: Publishing
docs.text:
The .github/workflows/docs.yml workflow:

  • Push to main: Builds and deploys the site to the production URL (root).
  • Pull request: Builds and deploys a preview to /pr/<number>/ and comments the preview URL on the PR.

Ensure GitHub Pages is enabled and set the source to Deploy from a branch → branch: gh-pages, folder: / (root).

docs.title: Architecture Decision Records
docs.text: This section lists the Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) for Initializer for Apache Maven™. Each ADR documents a significant design decision and its context.

docs.title: List of ADRs
docs.text:
ADR Title Status 001 — Project Generation for Apache Maven™ Choice of Maveniverse Toolbox for project generation Accepted

Click an ADR in the table or in the navigation to read its full content.

docs.title: ADR 001 — Project Generation for Apache Maven™
docs.text:
• Status: accepted
  • Decision makers: Support and Care Dev Team
  • Date: 2025-10-07
  • Related issues: GitHub #14, GitHub #6

docs.title: Context and Problem Description
docs.text:
Initializer for Apache Maven™ should help to generate a ready-to-use project structure for Apache Maven™. The core of the application is to generate the necessary project files.

In the past, others already solved this problem. Therefore, there is a chance to reuse their solution. We want to evaluate an existing solution and compare it with a custom solution based on a template engine.

docs.title: Considered Options
docs.text:
1. Reuse Apache Maven™ Archetype components
  2. Maveniverse Toolbox
  3. Custom solution based on a template engine

docs.title: Decision
docs.text:
Maveniverse Toolbox

We chose the Java-DSL approach, which is straightforward to use programmatically. The Toolbox already provides methods such as addDependencies that help to implement our requirements easily. It is implemented by an Apache Maven™ maintainer and is an active project.

docs.title: Positive Consequences
docs.text:
• Toolbox is a library from the Apache Maven™ community.
  • The Java DSL simplifies programmatic configuration.
  • It is actively maintained.

docs.title: Pros and Cons of the Options
Reuse Apache Maven™ Archetype Components
docs.text:
Apache Maven™ has its own mechanism for generating new projects, implemented as an Apache Maven™ plugin. This plugin has common components responsible for the generation part. Integrating these components is tricky because they depend on Apache Maven™ Core infrastructure. We would still need custom implementation to match our requirements (e.g. adding dependencies).

  • Good: Many ready-to-use templates exist.
  • Good: Generator implementation exists.
  • Bad: Custom adjustment for our requirements would be high.
  • Bad: Dependency hell.
  • Bad: Integration in other components is not easy (e.g. field-injection).

docs.title: Maveniverse Toolbox
docs.text:
Toolbox started as a showcase for MIMA Resolver, but provides a ready-to-use Java DSL for POM generation. This DSL is demonstrated in its own Apache Maven™ plugin and CLI tool, and can be used as a library.

  • Good: DSL-based.
  • Good: Good integration.
  • Good: Good abstraction of the Apache Maven™ infrastructure.

docs.title: Custom solution based on a template engine
docs.text:
We could start from scratch using a template engine that integrates well with Spring Boot.

  • Good: Full control.
  • Bad: Everything would have to be implemented from scratch.
  • Bad: Increased maintenance.
